section.foreign: A Monsieur Monsieur Norreis Chevalier et Governeur de la ville D'ostende.

page.lettertext:
fol.355r
S
r
, I can not choose in duty, being
earnestly moved by this
Councel,
and
e state of their warres requiring it
greatly, but intreat yo
w
againe, as I
have done by sundrie former, to assist
their present exploites, w
t
as many com-
panies, as yo
w
can possibly spare.
By all their intelligences, as well by
spies, as by others, and by
e confession
of those Deputies of
Bridges,
that are
nowe in
Berghen,
there is no apparance
at this present of any siege intended.
Not only their owne governo
rs
heere of
every towne and Province, but my
L.
Burgh
, and
S
r
Robert Sidney
, and
S
r
Thomas Morgan
are contented in this exig
e
t
to streine their garrisons to
e uttermost
for
e increase of the nombers in fielde.
And if yo
w
please in like maner to con-
curre w
t
e rest, for
e furtherance of
their generall, and most important en-
terprise, yo
w
shall in my opini
o
doe very
good
service to her
Ma
tie
and
e contrey. As
on
e other side, if they shouold chance to
be beaten of
e Enemie, for want of forces,
or to aband
o
their attemptes, yo
w
can
easely conjecture, where
e fault in part
will be cast. What hath passed in
e
campe,
and w
and what is towardes to
be atchieved, because this bearer can
declare it at large, I will not trouble yow w
t
rehersall:
but
wishing to all yo
r
actions most happy successe, betake yo
w
to God
Fr
o
e Hage. 26 1591
Yo
rs
assuredly and at co
m
aundem
t
Tho. Bodley.
